description: Borrowed from Middle French charnel, from Late Latin carnāle (“graveyard”), from Latin carnālis, or possibly an alteration of Anglo-Norman charner, from Medieval Latin carnārium (“charnel”).

adjectives.description: charnel (comparative more charnel, superlative most charnel)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to a charnel, deathlike, sepulchral.
A chapel attached to a mortuary.

description: From Old French charnel, from Latin cardinālis (“relating to a hinge”); related to French charnière.

entries.meaning: (historical) Part of a helm, now usually identified as the hinge (near the neck) by which the helm was secured to the breastplate.
